models.name: Opportunity Cost Thinking Model
models.description: Munger believes that opportunity cost is the most important but most easily overlooked concept in economics. When you choose to do one thing, you are actually giving up the opportunity to do everything else. Truly smart people ask: 'If I choose this, what will I lose?' Munger always considers in investment decisions: 'If I don't invest in this, what will I invest in?' This way of thinking helps him avoid many investments that seem attractive but actually have high opportunity costs.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Opportunity Cost Thinking Model

implementations.name: Opportunity Cost Thinking Model Practice Framework

models.name: Intuition Thinking Model
models.description: Munger says: 'Intuition is the condensation of experience.' True intuition doesn't arise out of nowhere, but is built on a solid foundation of knowledge and rich experience. When you master enough thinking models and repeatedly apply them in practice, your brain automatically internalizes these patterns, forming what we call 'intuition.' Munger emphasizes cultivating intuition based on rational analysis rather than blind feelings.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Intuition Thinking Model

models.name: Local vs Global Optimum Thinking Model
models.description: Munger often cites this concept to explain why we should avoid short-sighted decisions. Local optimum refers to the best choice within a certain range, but may not be the best choice overall. Munger says: 'If you only have a hammer, you'll treat all problems as nails.' This reminds us to step out of current thinking frameworks and think about problems from a more macro perspective, avoiding the local optimum trap.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Local vs Global Optimum Thinking Model

implementations.name: Local vs Global Optimum Thinking Model Practice Framework

models.name: Decision Tree Thinking Model
models.description: Munger believes that complex decisions should be broken down into a series of simple choices. The decision tree thinking model helps us systematically consider all possible choices and outcomes, evaluate the probability and impact of each choice. Munger says: 'If you can't clearly explain your investment logic, you shouldn't invest.' Decision trees are an important tool to help us clarify logic and avoid emotional decisions.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Decision Tree Thinking Model

implementations.name: Decision Tree Thinking Model Practice Framework

models.name: Sunk Cost Thinking Model
models.description: Munger says: 'Sunk costs are money already spent, no matter what decision you make, this money won't come back.' The core principle of this model is: sunk costs should not affect future decisions. Munger emphasizes that rational people should ignore costs already invested and only consider future benefits and costs. This is an important thinking tool to avoid the trap of 'continuing to invest more resources in failed projects.'

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Sunk Cost Thinking Model

implementations.name: Sunk Cost Thinking Model Practice Framework

models.name: Availability Bias Thinking Model
models.description: Munger says: 'The brain automatically chooses the easiest examples to think of, but this often misleads us.' Availability bias refers to people's tendency to judge the probability of events based on easily recalled examples. Munger emphasizes actively seeking counterexamples and contrary evidence to avoid being misled by easily accessible information. He often asks: 'What haven't I considered?'

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Availability Bias Thinking Model

implementations.name: Availability Bias Thinking Model Practice Framework

models.name: Confirmation Bias Thinking Model
models.description: Munger considers confirmation bias one of the most dangerous cognitive biases. People tend to seek, interpret, and remember information that supports their existing beliefs while ignoring or underestimating contrary evidence. Munger says: 'I always try to prove myself wrong, not prove myself right.' This way of thinking helps him avoid many investment traps.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Confirmation Bias Thinking Model

implementations.name: Confirmation Bias Thinking Model Practice Framework

models.name: Loss Aversion Thinking Model
models.description: Munger says: 'People's fear of loss is far greater than their desire for gain, this is a psychological legacy left by evolution.' Loss aversion refers to people's sensitivity to loss being far greater than their sensitivity to gain. Munger emphasizes being aware of this psychological tendency and objectively evaluating risks and benefits in decision-making, avoiding missing opportunities due to fear of loss.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Loss Aversion Thinking Model

implementations.name: Loss Aversion Thinking Model Practice Framework

models.name: Efficiency Thinking Model
models.description: Munger says: 'True efficiency is not simple speed, but continuous improvement in the right direction.' Efficiency thinking focuses on how to achieve maximum output with minimum resources. Munger emphasizes identifying and eliminating waste, optimizing processes, and improving productivity. He often asks: 'Can this process be simpler?'

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Efficiency Thinking Model

models.name: Time Machine Thinking Model
models.description: Munger says: 'History is the best teacher, many patterns will repeat.' Time machine thinking refers to the thinking method of predicting the future through historical experience and cases. Munger believes that studying history can help us avoid repeating others' mistakes, learn lessons from past successes and failures, and use historical wisdom to guide current decisions.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Time Machine Thinking Model

implementations.name: Time Machine Thinking Model Practice Framework

models.name: Asymmetry Thinking Model
models.description: Munger says: 'The world is asymmetric, a few people control most wealth, a few companies occupy most market share.' Asymmetry thinking model helps us recognize the asymmetry in the real world. Munger emphasizes finding investment opportunities with asymmetric advantages, such as companies with moats, platforms with network effects, etc.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Asymmetry Thinking Model

models.name: Compound Interest Principle
models.description: Compound interest refers to the compound growth effect generated by reinvesting interest. This model applies not only to financial investment but also to knowledge accumulation, skill development, and relationship building. Munger emphasizes that compound interest is one of the most powerful forces in the world, and we must be patient waiting for the compound effect to manifest.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Compound Interest Principle

models.name: Circle of Competence
models.description: Circle of competence refers to the range of areas that a person truly understands and excels at. This model emphasizes clearly understanding one's abilities and limitations, making decisions only within the circle of competence, and avoiding risks in areas one doesn't understand. Munger believes that expanding the circle of competence is more important than taking risks outside it.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Circle of Competence

models.name: Margin of Safety
models.description: Margin of safety refers to the buffer space left in investment or decision-making to cope with uncertainty and errors. This model emphasizes conservative estimation, preparing for worst-case scenarios, and ensuring that even if unexpected situations occur, they can be endured. Munger believes that margin of safety is a key element of successful investment.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Margin of Safety

models.name: Kahneman's Dual System Thinking Model
models.description: Munger highly praises Kahneman's dual system theory. The distinction between System 1 (fast, intuitive, automatic) and System 2 (slow, rational, effortful) helps us understand the source of cognitive biases. Munger emphasizes activating System 2 in important decisions to avoid being misled by System 1's intuition. He says: 'Slow thinking is the best way to avoid stupid mistakes.'

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Kahneman's Dual System Thinking Model

implementations.name: Kahneman's Dual System Thinking Model Practice Framework

models.name: Inversion Thinking Model
models.description: Inversion thinking refers to thinking about problems from the opposite angle and seeking reverse solutions. This model emphasizes breaking conventional thinking patterns and finding breakthroughs from the opposite side. Munger believes that many problems can find better solutions through reverse thinking.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Inversion Thinking Model

models.name: Occam's Razor
models.description: Occam's Razor principle holds that when explaining phenomena, one should choose the simplest theory with the fewest assumptions. This model emphasizes avoiding unnecessary complexity and pursuing simple and effective solutions. Munger believes that simple explanations are often closer to truth than complex ones.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Occam's Razor

models.name: First Principles Thinking
models.description: First principles thinking involves breaking down complex problems into their most basic elements and building up from there. This model emphasizes questioning assumptions and starting from fundamental truths rather than analogies. Munger believes that first principles thinking is essential for true innovation and breakthrough solutions.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of First Principles Thinking

models.name: Mental Models Latticework
models.description: Mental models latticework refers to the interconnected network of thinking models that work together to provide a comprehensive understanding of the world. Munger emphasizes building a diverse collection of mental models from different disciplines and using them in combination to analyze complex problems. He believes that the more models you have, the better you can understand reality.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Mental Models Latticework

models.name: Incentive Systems
models.description: Incentive systems refer to the rewards and punishments that drive human behavior. Munger emphasizes understanding how incentives shape behavior and outcomes. He believes that most problems can be understood by asking: 'What are the incentives?' Understanding incentive systems helps predict behavior and design better systems.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Incentive Systems

models.name: Scale Economics
models.description: Scale economics refers to the phenomenon where unit costs decrease as production scale expands. This model helps us understand why large enterprises are often more competitive than small ones and how to leverage scale effects. Munger believes that scale advantages are the core competitive advantages of many successful enterprises.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Scale Economics

models.name: Network Effects
models.description: Network effects occur when the value of a product or service increases as more people use it. This model helps understand why some platforms become dominant and how to identify and leverage network effects. Munger emphasizes the power of network effects in creating sustainable competitive advantages.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Network Effects

models.name: Moat Analysis
models.description: Moat analysis refers to identifying and evaluating the sustainable competitive advantages that protect a business from competition. Munger emphasizes looking for businesses with strong moats that can maintain profitability over long periods. He believes that understanding moats is crucial for long-term investment success.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Moat Analysis

models.name: Quality vs Price Thinking
models.description: Quality vs price thinking involves evaluating whether the quality of a product or service justifies its price. Munger emphasizes looking for situations where you can get high quality at a reasonable price, or where the price doesn't reflect the true value. This model helps make better purchasing and investment decisions.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Quality vs Price Thinking

implementations.name: Quality vs Price Thinking Practice Framework

models.name: Simplicity Principle
models.description: The simplicity principle holds that the best solutions are often the simplest ones. Munger emphasizes avoiding unnecessary complexity and focusing on the essential elements of problems. He believes that true wisdom lies in the ability to simplify complex problems and communicate them clearly.

papers.title: Theoretical Foundation and Practical Application of Simplicity Principle
